@guozhangwang, @hachikuji, @ewencp  - this is to disable the leave group on close. I've made the config internal, but I'm really not sure if this is the best way to do it. I just added another method, `ConfigDef#defineInternal`, but this needs to be public on `ConfigDef`. I'm not sure how else this can be done. Anyway, please take a look.

@ijuma @ewencp please have a look, thanks.
Apologies for previous trunk merge, was a mistake a few days ago.
I am wondering, if changing the JavaDocs is sufficient -- why not rename the parameters of the `Reducer` directly?

Refer to this link for build results (access rights to CI server needed): 
https://builds.apache.org/job/kafka-pr-jdk8-scala2.12/2054/
Test PASSed (JDK 8 and Scala 2.12).

https://builds.apache.org/job/kafka-pr-jdk7-scala2.10/2053/
Test PASSed (JDK 7 and Scala 2.10).
Updated.

@mjsax: I was thinking about this, too.

My current understanding is that the `Reducer` interface (to me) comes across as a simple binary function, and most probably -- though not explicitly defined in a contract as such -- an associative binary function at that.  That said, if `Reducer` is used nowhere else we may want to be more explicit, as you said.

When reworking the JavaDocs, I had the same thought that `Reducer` interface is a simple binary function and agnostic if the parameters are "raw values" of "aggregates". That was the reason why I did not change anything. But in our code base, we only use it with "currentAgg" and "newValue" and as we describe this explicitly in the JavaDocs, we could also change the interface directly IMHO.

But it's hard to judge how to keep a nice "balance" and not mess with clean abstractions...

@apurvam : added FetcherTest.testUpdateFetchPositionsNoneCommittedNoResetStrategy()

@sjmittal I see. Yeah it seems with potential multi-way dead lock it won't work: For example, imagine thread1 owning task1/2, thread2 owning task 3/4, thread3 owning task 5/6, and lets assume thread1 is kicked and the new assignment is thread2 -> task 1/3/4 and thread3 -> task 2/5/6, assuming thread1 already grab lock on task1 before being kicked but not on task2, then thread2 trying to grab locks for task 1/3/4 will be blocked on 1, but thread3 grabbing locks on 2/5/6 happen to succeed on 2 and proceeds, we will leave with thread1 and thread2 deadlocked then.
Jenkins failures seem to be related to https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/KAFKA-4841. There is a fix ongoing: https://github.com/apache/kafka/pull/2641
Merged to trunk and cherry-picked to 0.10.2.
@ijuma My bad. I should have removed that earlier. Problem fixed now.

@hachikuji @ijuma @becketqin Thank you for review!
@ijuma - script updated  `./jmh-benchmarks/jmh.sh` works now

@ijuma This is ready for another look. Several changes:

1. As discussed offline, I've removed support for the unsigned encoding.
2. I've moved `ByteBufferInputStream` and `ByteBufferOutputStream` into `utils`. I did the same thing in the message format patch, but thought I might as well do it here so that I didn't have to mess with the import control file in order to use these classes for testing.
3. A few minor improvements to the serdes themselves plus the additional test cases. I actually did find a bug handling one of the error cases, so one more win for unit tests!
Really looking forward to this, thanks @hrafzali
